description: Write down the numbers 1,2,3,... but omit any number (such as 12 or 23 or 31 ...) which appears in the concatenation of all earlier terms.
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..10000
Nick Hobson, Python program for this sequence
example: 12 is omitted since we see "1,2" at the beginning of the sequence; 101 is omitted because we can see "10,1[1]"; etc.
mathematica: Clear[a]; a[1] = 1; s = "1"; a[n_] := a[n] = Catch[ For[k = a[n-1] + 1, True, k++, If[ StringFreeQ[s, t = ToString[k]], s = s <> t; Throw[k] ] ] ]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 75}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jan 09 2013 *)
prog: (Python) see Hobson link(Haskell)import Data.List (isInfixOf)a048991 n = a048991_list !! (n-1)a048991_list = f [1..] [] where   f (x:xs) ys | xs' `isInfixOf` ys = f xs ys               | otherwise          = x : f xs (xs' ++ ys)               where xs' = reverse $ show x-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Dec 05 2011
crossrefs: See A048992 for the omitted numbers.
author: Bernardo Recamán (ignotus(AT)hotmail.com)
